MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Science Parks Report.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if he has received and considered the report on science parks from the Science Technology and Innovation Advisory Council; if a decision to give EU structural funding towards such a science park has been made; and if Abbostown College is the number one location.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. E. Kenny) Richard Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. E. Kenny)
Speaker.P: The Science, Technology and Innovation Advisory Council have just reported to me in relation to their review of Irish science and technology policy as a whole. There is a separate working group established by my Department specifically to examine the feasibility of setting up a science and technology park in the Dublin area.
This latter working group is still considering the issue but I expect it to make a report on the matter very shortly.

MainHeading.P: I expect that the group will, in their report, address the issues of potential funding for such a development as well as possible sites, having regard to existing and planned public and private sector industrial development in the Dublin area over the next few years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: his views on the withdrawal of funding under the Horizon Initiative which has led to the withdrawal of the work options programme run by DIA, Mountjoy Square, Dublin 1, under the auspices of St. Michael's House; if he will have the programme restored; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. E. Kenny) Richard Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Mr. E. Kenny)
Speaker.P: The EU Horizon Initiative operated from 1992 to 1994 and supported innovative pilot projects over a defined period.

It was made clear to all project promoters at the outset that the funding period was finite. All promoters were also made aware of the essential difference between funding under the Horizon Initiative and assistance funded through mainstream national programmes. Under the criteria for funding as set out by the European Commission no Horizon project may receive continuous funding from the European Social Fund on completion of the pilot phase.

Accordingly, Horizon funding was not withdrawn from the project in question. Like all 95 Horizon projects which were cofunded in the 1992 to 1994 phase of the programme the St. Michael's House project completed the full pilot phase. The first Horizon programme ceased to be operational at the end of 1994. A new set of human resources community initiatives which will include an Horizon programme, will be operational in the course of this year. My Department is now involved in a national information campaign to publicise the EU human resources initiat-ives to prospective participants.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - MMDS System.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself with the current operation of the MMDS system; the areas currently served by the system; the level of satisfaction among consumers in relation to the system; and in the event of this not being satisfactory, the alternative plans, if any, he has in place in relation to the provision of the service throughout the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: MMDS systems are now in operation in all of the ten franchise areas throughout the country. I am, however, concerned that there are still some of these areas and notably in Counties Donegal and Mayo, where an acceptable level of coverage has not yet been achieved.
Where MMDS is in operation, it provides a high quality service and a broad range of channels and I am not aware of any significant level of dissatisfaction among customers who avail of it.

MainHeading.P: I am aware that in certain areas there is concern about the cost of the MMDS system in comparison with that of existing community deflector schemes and about the lack of choice. In accordance with the Government's Programme of Renewal, I am examining ways in which those concerns can be addressed, subject, of course, to proper frequency management and in compliance with our international obligations in that regard.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Defence Forces Data.

Qst.Quest: his intentions regarding the implementation of the Price Waterhouse report on the future of army barracks, with particular regard to the barracks at Ballincollig, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Coveney) Minister for Defence (Mr. Coveney)
Speaker.P: There are no plans to alter the status of Murphy Barracks, Ballincollig, County Cork, or any other permanently occupied military barracks or post with the sole exception of Collins Barracks, Dublin the closure of which has already been announced.

The firm of Price Waterhouse Management Consultants was engaged to assist the Efficiency Audit Group (EAG) in their review of the Defence Forces. The report of the EAG has not yet been considered by the Government. Accordingly, no decisions have been taken as a result of the EAG review.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Ryan Mr. S. Ryan
Qst.Quest: the number of officers of Na Buan Óglaigh on 31 December 1994, who were holding acting higher ranks; the number of such appointments which are unpaid; the number of such ranks occassioned by United Nations, EU or other missions; the higher ranks held by Command and Corps; the reasons for such a number of acting higher paid ranks; and the number of officers by rank, corps and command who are serving beyond their normal retirement date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Coveney) Minister for Defence (Mr. Coveney)
Speaker.P: There were 198 officers of the Permanent Defence Force serving in acting ranks on 31 December, 1994. A breakdown on this number by rank, Corps and Command is given in the schedule which I will circulate with the Official Report.

Promotion to acting rank, mainly arises when officers are promoted to fill temporary vacancies created by the assignment of personnel on duty overseas with United Nations, European Union or other missions. Officers so promoted are normally made substantive in their new rank after a period of service in an acting capacity. Pay and allowances are the same for acting and substantive ranks.
On 31 December, 1994, 24 officers of the Permanent Defence Force were serving beyond normal retirement age. A breakdown of this number by rank, Corps and Command is given in the attached schedule.
